block.p: Leaders of Two Koreas Confer in Pyongyang Opening formalities at the first summit meeting between North and South Korea seemed surprisingly relaxed, exceeding the expectations of many people, including perhaps those of the principals themselves, Kim Jong Il of the North and Kim Dae Jung of the South. During a 27 minute-meeting, they discussed the need to establish a hotline, and talks today are expected to focus on issues that divide the two countries.

Italy Pardons Papal Attacker The president of Italy pardoned Mehmet Ali Agca, 42, left, who tried to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981, clearing the way for his extradition to Turkey, where he was convicted in absentia of murdering a journalist in 1978.

Russia Arrests Media Mogul The Kremlin's chief prosecutor jailed Vladimir Gusinsky, the head of a media empire that has been sharply critical of the government, immediately rousing fears of a clampdown on the press. But President Vladimir V. Putin said the arrest was an unwelcome surprise to him.
Russian officials have told the United States that they are developing a system for downing ballistic missiles soon after they are launched.

U.S. Fines Military Contractor Lockheed Martin agreed to pay $13 million to settle a case involving the sale of satellite technology to China in 1994. It was accused of violating arms export laws. A spokesman said Lockheed neither admitted nor denied the accusations.
Push to Upgrade U.N. Forces Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke said the United Nations must transform its civilian-run peacekeeping department into a larger and more effective military-style operation.
Chile Inquiry for Pinochet Era The military agreed to search for the remains of 1,200 dissidents who disappeared during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

Syrian Leader Is Buried Hafez al-Assad was buried in his hilltop hometown, Qardaha, after daylong ceremonies. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met briefly with his son and designated successor, Bashar al-Assad, and said she found him ready to pursue peace talks with Israel.

Gore Cites Clinton Record In a Call for New Spending Vice President Al Gore, invoking the economic record of President Clinton, called for a new retirement program to supplement Social Security, elimination of the nation's debt in 12 years, modest tax cuts and systematic spending increases for education, health care and the environment. His speech in Manhattan was the first in a series elaborating on his message of ''prosperity and progress.''

Mr. Gore suggested that recent studies citing legal errors in death penalty cases could prompt a fresh evaluation of the nation's use of capital punishment. But he did not suggest that he was ready to abandon his support for the death penalty.

Speaker Aims to Hold House Congressional officials said Speaker J. Dennis Hastert planned to unveil a plan today to raise $16 million from House Republicans to use in especially close races this fall, to protect the Republicans' six-seat majority and erode a substantial Democratic edge at the bank.

G.O.P. Shift on Drug Benefit House Republicans said the federal government must be ''the insurer of last resort'' to guarantee that drug coverage is available to all Medicare beneficiaries. The announcement signified a shift from their previous position, that private insurance was the only way to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly.

Delay in Reporting Lost Secrets The Energy Department acknowledged that managers at the Los Alamos National Laboratory waited more than three weeks before reporting the loss of computer hard drives that held important nuclear secrets. The acknowledgment came as Energy Secretary Bill Richardson and his department faced harsh criticism in Congress. Officials said six Los Alamos employees had been placed on leave. The F.B.I. is investigating the disappearance.

Ground-Collision Risk Rising The National Transportation Safety Board said the risk of airplane collisions on the ground was growing because of a jump in airport traffic, and that a computer system designed to prevent planes from blundering onto the wrong runway, now 10 years behind schedule, would not be good enough.
'Genius Grants' Awarded The MacArthur Foundation announced 25 recipients of its $500,000 fellowships, given for extraordinary creativity and promise.

More Women Cite Attacks In Central Park on Sunday Officials said 22 women had come forward to report being attacked by groups of young men; 5 women said they were robbed. Police officials were also investigating whether officers had responded adequately as rude behavior evolved into mob action and sexual attacks.

Death Penalty to Be Sought Lawyers said Attorney General Janet Reno had authorized federal prosecutors in Manhattan to seek the death penalty for a second defendant in the embassy bombings in Africa in 1998, but not for a third.

Deal on Pension Increases State leaders in Albany reached agreement on giving annual cost-of-living pension increases to retired state and local government workers. The plan would cost New York City more than $500 million a year.
And Now, Elevator News Several companies are preparing to outfit office elevators in New York and elsewhere with silent video screens that show ads and breaking news from the Internet.

Carnegie Hill High-Rise Rejected The City Landmarks Commission rejected plans for a 17-story apartment tower at Madison Avenue and East 91st Street, in the Carnegie Hill Historic District, that many Upper East Side residents had opposed.

Money and Pupil Performance The findings of a New York Times analysis of how the city's 32 community school districts allocate money contradict two common assumptions about educational disparities: It found that districts with the highest-performing students received the least amount of money per pupil, and that those districts also had the most crowded classrooms.

Appeal Phase of Microsoft Case Microsoft appealed its antitrust ruling to an appellate court that two years ago issued a ruling favorable to the company. In its filing yesterday, Microsoft said the trial judge had committed numerous serious errors. The Justice Department moved to take the case directly to the Supreme Court, which could force the appellate court to step aside.

French Suitor for Seagram Seagram and Vivendi, the French media conglomerate, are expected to announce today that Vivendi is negotiating to buy Seagram for $30.6 billion. Beyond its liquor business, Seagram's interests include Polygram, Universal Pictures, theme parks and a stake in USA Networks.

Regional Bell Expanding The Justice Department recommended that SBC Communications, the nation's biggest local phone carrier, be allowed to sell long-distance services to its customers in Texas. If the F.C.C. agrees, as expected, SBC will become the second regional Bell to enter the long-distance market.
Stock Markets Advance The Dow rose 57.63 points, to 10,621.84; the S.& P. 500 climbed 23.44 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,469.44; and the Nasdaq was up 83.15 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,851.06.
